keyTakeAways: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges.
Santos claims the prosecution was not political and that his time in prison, including solitary confinement, has led him to a 'very large slice of humble pie.'
Santos asserts that he did not commit fraud and that the investment made to win an election was legitimate, denying wrongdoing despite being found guilty.
Former colleagues like Rep. Nick LaLota and Rep. Andrew Garbarino criticized Santos, calling his crimes severe and stating he has shown no remorse or sufficient restitution.
Santos has no obligation to pay further fines, restitution, or probation conditions following the commutation.
Santos expressed interest in prison reform and stated he will not return to politics in the next decade.
Santos said he is now focused on the future, apologizing to the American public and his former district, and has been inspired by prison experience to advocate for reform.

summaryOfNewsArticle: George Santos, a former U.S. Representative from New York, was released from prison after President Donald Trump commuted his seven-year sentence for fraud charges related to falsified campaign finances. Santos dismissed critics, claiming the prosecution was not political and that he has undergone a 'very large slice of humble pie' during his incarceration. Despite public criticism from fellow Republicans like Nick LaLota and Andrew Garbarino, who condemned his actions and lack of remorse, Santos maintains he did not commit fraud and insists he is now focused on personal growth, prison reform, and future civic engagement. He expressed no intention of returning to politics in the next decade and emphasized his desire to contribute to systemic reform without partisanship. The article underscores the political controversy surrounding the commutation and the broader implications for accountability, public trust, and executive power in the justice system.
title: George Santos maintains his prosecution was political, says he’s had a ‘very large slice of humble pie’
